newsitem.title: JAPAN: Murdoch seeks to tie up with PerfecTV in Japan.
newsitem.headline: Murdoch seeks to tie up with PerfecTV in Japan.

text.p: Australia's News Corp, planning a multi-channel digital satellite broadcasting service in Japan to start next year, hopes to tie up with Japanese rival PerfecTV, a News spokeswoman said on Thursday.
She quoted visiting media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp, as saying he hoped to allow Japanese viewers to access both providers' satellite services through a single receiver and dish.
Murdoch revealed the plan in press interviews, she said.
News plans to offer a 150-channel JSkyB service in Japan through a joint venture with Softbank Corp.
The joint venture is expected to be granted a licence for a TV service using the JCSAT-3 satellite this autumn. The service is expected to start late next year.

The PerfecTV group, headed by Itochu Corp, will launch Japan's first digital satellite broadcasting service in October. It plans to offer a 60-channel service and aims to acquire 300,000 subscribers in the initial year.
A PerfecTV spokeswoman said the company had not yet received such a request from News, but added that the proposed tie-up was not impossible.
"There is no official request yet. But the (tie-up) would benefit our subscribers," she said.
Analysts say News is seeking to link up with PerfecTV because of the large number of existing terrestrial TV channels in Japan.
"The market is a bit crowded and demand for pay-per-view satellite TVs may be slow for a while," said an industry official.
JSkyB will be followed by DirecTV, a unit of Hughes Electronics Corp, which plans to launch 100-channel digital satellite broadcasting in Japan in 1997.
The media tycoon's entry into Japan's broadcasting and media market has stirred controversy in the industry, normally immune to realignments and foreign offensives.
Murdoch earlier this week sought to appoint John McBride, head of News Corp's Japan unit, as an executive of its affiliate Asahi National Broadcasting.
But the request was reportedly rejected on the grounds that Japanese law forbids foreigners from assuming executive posts at Japanese broadcasting companies.
News and Softbank jointly acquired Japanese media company Obunsha Media for 41.75 billion yen ($383 million). Obunsha has a 21.4 percent stake in Asahi National Broadcasting Co, known as TV Asahi.
The Asahi Shimbun group is the largest shareholder in TV Asahi, holding a 38.3 percent stake in the broadcaster. ($1=109 yen)
